definition: Li Zhi (1527-1602), late Ming philosopher, historian and writer
plum
surname Li
gifts to superiors

sentences.english: Chapter One illustrates the origin of the mind theory that produces Li's thoughts.
sentences.chinese: 第一章论述李贽求真思想所产生的心学渊源。

sentences.english: Li Zhi and humanists are their thought's representatives.
sentences.chinese: 李贽和人文主义者就是他们的思想代表。

sentences.english: Xingquan Ming is a counterfeit writing in the name of U Zhi.
sentences.chinese: 《醒泉铭》实为假冒李贽之名的伪作。

sentences.english: Lizhi is a literature critic of the Chinese classical literature.
sentences.chinese: 李贽是中国古典文学的评点家。

sentences.english: Li Zhi was an enlightening thinker at later Ming Dynasty.
sentences.chinese: 李贽，晚明时期的启蒙思想家。

sentences.english: Li Zhi is an ideologist, not famous for his poems.
sentences.chinese: 李贽是位思想家，不以诗名。

sentences.english: What Li Zhi brings common people firstly is endless disputes.
sentences.chinese: 李贽带给世人的，首先是没完没了的争议。

sentences.english: Finally , evaluate the historical significance of Li Zhi's novel theory.
sentences.chinese: 最后评价了李贽小说理论的历史意义。

sentences.english: Lizhi is a famous controversy ideologist in the Chinese idealistic history .
sentences.chinese: 李贽，在中国思想史上是一位富有争议的思想家。

definition: Huang Zongxi (1610-1695), scholar and writer of the Ming-Qing transition
Gu Yanwu (1613-1682), late Ming and early Qing Confucian philosopher, linguist and historian, played a founding role in phonology of early Chinese, author of Rizhilu or Record of daily study 日知錄|日知录
Zhu Xi or Chu Hsi (1130-1200), also known as Master Zhu 朱子, Song dynasty Confucian writer and propagandist, founder of neo-Confucianism
Wang Fuzhi (1619-1692), wide-ranging scholar of the Ming-Qing transition
Hai Rui (1514-1587), Ming politician, famous for honesty and integrity
Hairui township in Taitung County 臺東縣|台东县[Tai2 dong1 Xian4], southeast Taiwan
scholar of the rationalist school of Neo-Confucianism 理學|理学[Li3 xue2]
Zhang Pu (1602-1641), Ming dynasty scholar and prolific writer, proponent of 複社|复社[fu4 she4] cultural renewal movement, author of Five tombstone inscriptions 五人墓碑記|五人墓碑记[wu3 ren2 mu4 bei1 ji4]
Master Zhu, another name for Zhu Xi 朱熹
Cheng Yi (1033-1107), Song neo-Confucian scholar
Zhang Juzheng (1525-1582), Grand Secretary during the Ming dynasty, credited with bringing the dynasty to its apogee
Yuan Hongdao (1568-1610), Ming dynasty poet and travel writer
Xu Wei, Chinese painter
Feng Menglong (1574-1646), late Ming dynasty novelist writing in colloquial (baihua), author of Stories Old and New 古今小說|古今小说[Gu3 jin1 Xiao3 shuo1]
School of Mind/Neo-Confucian Idealistic School (from Song to mid-Qing times, c. 1000-1750, typified by the teachings of Wang Yangming 王陽明|王阳明[Wang2 Yang2 ming2])
Zhang Taiyan (1869-1936), scholar, journalist, revolutionary and leading intellectual around the time of the Xinhai revolution
Confucianism
